title: How to Make Green Chocolate Chip Cookies

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 375ºF (190ºC).
steps.description: Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper, then set them aside.

steps.headline: Mix together the flour, baking soda, and baking powder.
steps.description: Pour the flour into a small mixing bowl. Add both the baking soda and the baking powder. Stir everything together with a whisk, then set the bowl aside.

steps.headline: Cream the sugar and butter.
steps.description: You can do this by hand in a large bowl with a handheld beater. You can also use a mixer or a food processor fitted with whisks.

steps.headline: Add in the egg, food coloring, and vanilla extract.
steps.description: Mix everything together well until the color and texture are uniform. Scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed to ensure that everything mixes in evenly. You see no streaks or swirls of food coloring or egg yolk. You can use up to 10 or so drops of food coloring if you want a deeper green color. If you can't find any liquid food coloring, try 3 drops of gel food coloring instead. For a minty flavor, use 1 teaspoon of peppermint extract instead of the vanilla.

steps.headline: Gradually add the flour mixture into the butter mixture.
steps.description: Blend in half of the flour mixture into the butter mixture using a slow speed setting. Add in the rest of the flour mixture, and blend again.

steps.headline: Fold the chocolate chips into the batter.
steps.description: Pour the chocolate chips on top of the batter. Fold them in by hand using a rubber spatula. Do not use a beater, mixer, or food processor for this, or the friction will cause too much heat and melt the chocolate chips. Try it with mint chocolate chips instead.

steps.headline: Scoop the dough onto the prepared parchment paper.
steps.description: Use a cookie scoop or your hands to roll the dough into balls. Aim to make them about 1-inch (2.54-centimeter) wide. Arrange the balls onto the cookie sheets, spaced several inches/centimeters apart. Flatten each ball slightly to create a disk. Don't place the cookies too close together, otherwise they will smoosh into one big cookie.

steps.headline: Bake the cookies for 10 minutes.
steps.description: They are ready when the edges turn a light golden color. If your oven is small, you will need to bake the cookies on different racks; remember to rotate the racks halfway through baking.

steps.headline: Allow the cookies to cool on a rack before serving them.
steps.description: Let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for about 5 minutes, then transfer them to a wire cooling rack. Let them finish cooling for at least 10 minutes before serving them.

steps.headline: Mix together all of the dry ingredients, except for the sugars.
steps.description: Pour the flour into a large mixing bowl. Add the baking powder, baking soda, and the salt. Stir them together, then add in the chocolate chips. Toss everything together gently. This recipe requires a 12 to 24-hour chilling period. Plan ahead!

steps.headline: Mix the sugars, oil, and water together in a different bowl.
steps.description: Pour both the white and the brown sugars into another large mixing bow. Pour in the canola oil and the water. Whisk them together for about 2 minutes. You can speed up the process by using a handheld beater, a stand mixer, or a food processor fitted with whisks. If you don't have canola oil, you can use another type of oil with a neutral flavor to it, such as grapeseed. If the brown sugar has clumps in it, be sure to break them up first before adding it to the bowl. If you can't find a vegan-friendly white sugar, use 1 cup (200 grams) of brown sugar instead of a combination of white and brown sugar.

steps.headline: Add the vanilla extract and food coloring to the sugar mixture.
steps.description: Keep stirring until the color and texture are consistent. If you don't have liquid food coloring, try 3 drops of gel food coloring instead.If you want the cookies to have a minty flavor, use 1 teaspoon of peppermint extract instead of the vanilla. You can use more food coloring if the color is not strong enough for you.

steps.headline: Stir the flour mixture into the sugar mixture.
steps.description: You can do this with a wooden spoon or a rubber spatula. Scrape down the sides of the bowl, as needed, and stop when there is no flour left. Do not over-mix the batter.

steps.headline: Chill the dough in the fridge for 12 to 24 hours.
steps.description: Cover the bowl with a sheet of plastic wrap, then stick it in the fridge. Leave it there for 12 to 24 hours. This is very important; if you skip this step, the cookies will spread out too much while baking.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C).
steps.description: Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper. Do this when the dough is done chilling.

steps.headline: Scoop the dough onto the prepared baking sheets and flatten it.
steps.description: Use a small ice cream scoop or a cookie scoop to form the dough into balls. Gently flatten each ball to a 2-inch (508-centimeter) wide disk. Consider freezing the cookies for 10 minutes. This will help them keep their shape.

steps.headline: Bake the cookies for 12 to 13 minutes.
steps.description: They are ready when the edges turn golden. If your oven is not big enough to fit the baking sheets, you will need to put them on separate racks. If you end up doing this, be sure to switch the baking sheets around halfway through baking.

steps.headline: Allow the cookies to cool before serving them.
steps.description: Let them cool on the baking sheet for about 5 minutes first before transferring them to a wire cooling rack. Let them finish cooling (about 10 minutes) before serving them.

text: Making Classic Cookies Preheat your oven to 375ºF (190ºC). Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper, then set them aside. Mix together the flour, baking soda, and baking powder. Pour the flour into a small mixing bowl. Add both the baking soda and the baking powder. Stir everything together with a whisk, then set the bowl aside. Cream the sugar and butter. You can do this by hand in a large bowl with a handheld beater. You can also use a mixer or a food processor fitted with whisks. Add in the egg, food coloring, and vanilla extract. Mix everything together well until the color and texture are uniform. Scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed to ensure that everything mixes in evenly. You see no streaks or swirls of food coloring or egg yolk. You can use up to 10 or so drops of food coloring if you want a deeper green color. If you can't find any liquid food coloring, try 3 drops of gel food coloring instead. For a minty flavor, use 1 teaspoon of peppermint extract instead of the vanilla. Gradually add the flour mixture into the butter mixture. Blend in half of the flour mixture into the butter mixture using a slow speed setting. Add in the rest of the flour mixture, and blend again. Fold the chocolate chips into the batter. Pour the chocolate chips on top of the batter. Fold them in by hand using a rubber spatula. Do not use a beater, mixer, or food processor for this, or the friction will cause too much heat and melt the chocolate chips. Try it with mint chocolate chips instead. Scoop the dough onto the prepared parchment paper. Use a cookie scoop or your hands to roll the dough into balls. Aim to make them about 1-inch (2.54-centimeter) wide. Arrange the balls onto the cookie sheets, spaced several inches/centimeters apart. Flatten each ball slightly to create a disk. Don't place the cookies too close together, otherwise they will smoosh into one big cookie. Bake the cookies for 10 minutes. They are ready when the edges turn a light golden color. If your oven is small, you will need to bake the cookies on different racks; remember to rotate the racks halfway through baking. Allow the cookies to cool on a rack before serving them. Let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for about 5 minutes, then transfer them to a wire cooling rack. Let them finish cooling for at least 10 minutes before serving them. Making Vegan Cookies Mix together all of the dry ingredients, except for the sugars. Pour the flour into a large mixing bowl. Add the baking powder, baking soda, and the salt. Stir them together, then add in the chocolate chips. Toss everything together gently. This recipe requires a 12 to 24-hour chilling period. Plan ahead! Mix the sugars, oil, and water together in a different bowl. Pour both the white and the brown sugars into another large mixing bow. Pour in the canola oil and the water. Whisk them together for about 2 minutes. You can speed up the process by using a handheld beater, a stand mixer, or a food processor fitted with whisks. If you don't have canola oil, you can use another type of oil with a neutral flavor to it, such as grapeseed. If the brown sugar has clumps in it, be sure to break them up first before adding it to the bowl. If you can't find a vegan-friendly white sugar, use 1 cup (200 grams) of brown sugar instead of a combination of white and brown sugar. Add the vanilla extract and food coloring to the sugar mixture. Keep stirring until the color and texture are consistent. If you don't have liquid food coloring, try 3 drops of gel food coloring instead.If you want the cookies to have a minty flavor, use 1 teaspoon of peppermint extract instead of the vanilla. You can use more food coloring if the color is not strong enough for you. Stir the flour mixture into the sugar mixture. You can do this with a wooden spoon or a rubber spatula. Scrape down the sides of the bowl, as needed, and stop when there is no flour left. Do not over-mix the batter. Chill the dough in the fridge for 12 to 24 hours. Cover the bowl with a sheet of plastic wrap, then stick it in the fridge. Leave it there for 12 to 24 hours. This is very important; if you skip this step, the cookies will spread out too much while baking. Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C). Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper. Do this when the dough is done chilling. Scoop the dough onto the prepared baking sheets and flatten it. Use a small ice cream scoop or a cookie scoop to form the dough into balls. Gently flatten each ball to a 2-inch (508-centimeter) wide disk. Consider freezing the cookies for 10 minutes. This will help them keep their shape. Bake the cookies for 12 to 13 minutes. They are ready when the edges turn golden. If your oven is not big enough to fit the baking sheets, you will need to put them on separate racks. If you end up doing this, be sure to switch the baking sheets around halfway through baking. Allow the cookies to cool before serving them. Let them cool on the baking sheet for about 5 minutes first before transferring them to a wire cooling rack. Let them finish cooling (about 10 minutes) before serving them.
sentences: Making Classic Cookies Preheat your oven to 375ºF (190ºC).
Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper, then set them aside.
Mix together the flour, baking soda, and baking powder.
Pour the flour into a small mixing bowl.
Add both the baking soda and the baking powder.
Stir everything together with a whisk, then set the bowl aside.
Cream the sugar and butter.
You can do this by hand in a large bowl with a handheld beater.
You can also use a mixer or a food processor fitted with whisks.
Add in the egg, food coloring, and vanilla extract.
Mix everything together well until the color and texture are uniform.
Scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed to ensure that everything mixes in evenly.
You see no streaks or swirls of food coloring or egg yolk.
You can use up to 10 or so drops of food coloring if you want a deeper green color.
If you can't find any liquid food coloring, try 3 drops of gel food coloring instead.
For a minty flavor, use 1 teaspoon of peppermint extract instead of the vanilla.
Gradually add the flour mixture into the butter mixture.
Blend in half of the flour mixture into the butter mixture using a slow speed setting.
Add in the rest of the flour mixture, and blend again.
Fold the chocolate chips into the batter.
Pour the chocolate chips on top of the batter.
Fold them in by hand using a rubber spatula.
Do not use a beater, mixer, or food processor for this, or the friction will cause too much heat and melt the chocolate chips.
Try it with mint chocolate chips instead.
Scoop the dough onto the prepared parchment paper.
Use a cookie scoop or your hands to roll the dough into balls.
Aim to make them about 1-inch (2.54-centimeter) wide.
Arrange the balls onto the cookie sheets, spaced several inches/centimeters apart.
Flatten each ball slightly to create a disk.
Don't place the cookies too close together, otherwise they will smoosh into one big cookie.
Bake the cookies for 10 minutes.
They are ready when the edges turn a light golden color.
If your oven is small, you will need to bake the cookies on different racks; remember to rotate the racks halfway through baking.
Allow the cookies to cool on a rack before serving them.
Let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for about 5 minutes, then transfer them to a wire cooling rack.
Let them finish cooling for at least 10 minutes before serving them.
Making Vegan Cookies Mix together all of the dry ingredients, except for the sugars.
Pour the flour into a large mixing bowl.
Add the baking powder, baking soda, and the salt.
Stir them together, then add in the chocolate chips.
Toss everything together gently.
This recipe requires a 12 to 24-hour chilling period.
Plan ahead!
Mix the sugars, oil, and water together in a different bowl.
Pour both the white and the brown sugars into another large mixing bow.
Pour in the canola oil and the water.
Whisk them together for about 2 minutes.
You can speed up the process by using a handheld beater, a stand mixer, or a food processor fitted with whisks.
If you don't have canola oil, you can use another type of oil with a neutral flavor to it, such as grapeseed.
If the brown sugar has clumps in it, be sure to break them up first before adding it to the bowl.
If you can't find a vegan-friendly white sugar, use 1 cup (200 grams) of brown sugar instead of a combination of white and brown sugar.
Add the vanilla extract and food coloring to the sugar mixture.
Keep stirring until the color and texture are consistent.
If you don't have liquid food coloring, try 3 drops of gel food coloring instead.If you want the cookies to have a minty flavor, use 1 teaspoon of peppermint extract instead of the vanilla.
You can use more food coloring if the color is not strong enough for you.
Stir the flour mixture into the sugar mixture.
You can do this with a wooden spoon or a rubber spatula.
Scrape down the sides of the bowl, as needed, and stop when there is no flour left.
Do not over-mix the batter.
Chill the dough in the fridge for 12 to 24 hours.
Cover the bowl with a sheet of plastic wrap, then stick it in the fridge.
Leave it there for 12 to 24 hours.
This is very important; if you skip this step, the cookies will spread out too much while baking.
Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C).
Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper.
Do this when the dough is done chilling.
Scoop the dough onto the prepared baking sheets and flatten it.
Use a small ice cream scoop or a cookie scoop to form the dough into balls.
Gently flatten each ball to a 2-inch (508-centimeter) wide disk.
Consider freezing the cookies for 10 minutes.
This will help them keep their shape.
Bake the cookies for 12 to 13 minutes.
They are ready when the edges turn golden.
If your oven is not big enough to fit the baking sheets, you will need to put them on separate racks.
If you end up doing this, be sure to switch the baking sheets around halfway through baking.
Allow the cookies to cool before serving them.
Let them cool on the baking sheet for about 5 minutes first before transferring them to a wire cooling rack.
Let them finish cooling (about 10 minutes) before serving them.
tyn_section: Cookie scoop or ice cream scoop
